sen.j: 賽銭（さいせん）とは、神 (神道)や仏に供える金銭のことである。
sen.e: Saisen is money offered to the gods (Shinto), Buddhist images and so on.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Saisen is money offered to the gods (Shinto), Buddha and so on.
sen.cmt: 「仏像」に対して供えるのではなく、仏様に対して供えるのでBuddhist images→Buddhasに変更

sen.j: 多くは神社、寺院の前に置いてある賽銭箱に投入する金銭のことを言う。
sen.e: It mainly refers to money which is thrown in Saisenbako (offertory boxes) placed in front of shrines or temples.

sen.j: 参拝者は賽銭箱に金銭を投入した後、神社なら拍手 (神道)、寺院なら合掌し、目を閉じながら神仏への願い事やお礼を心の中で唱える。
sen.e: After throwing money in Saisenbako, visitors clap their hands at shrines (Shinto) or put their palms together at temples, and then they pray for their wishes or offer their thanks to Shinto and Buddhist deities in their minds.

sen.j: 金額は決まっていないが、多くの人は硬貨を賽銭として投入している。
sen.e: Although the amount of Saisen is not fixed, many people throw in coins as Saisen.

sen.e: A recent example is "shiju-goen"(four 10-yen coins and a 5-yen coin) which means forming a lot of good relationships.

sen.j: 初詣では「福来い（2,951円）」を賽銭として投入する自営業者も多い。
sen.e: In hatsumode (the practice of visiting a shrine or temple at the beginning of the New Year), many self-employed people throw in as Saisen "fuku-koi"(2,951yen) which means bringing good luck.

sen.e: Sometimes, worshipers place Saisen before Jizo Bosatsu (Jizo Bodhisattva statues) or shintai (an object of worship housed in a Shinto shrine and believed to contain the spirit of a deity) even without Saisenbako.
